sense.name: Annoy, harass, or mock, perhaps playfully.
sense.examples: The children teased the boy because of his stammer. The children teased the new teacher. The workers teased him when he wore a jacket and tie.

sense.name: Arouse hope, desire, or curiousity without satisfying them.
sense.examples: The advertisement is intended to tease the customers. She has a way of teasing men with her flirtatious behavior.

sense.name: Physically separate, disentangle, or tear into pieces.
sense.examples: Tease tissues for the microscopic examinations. Tease the wool to prepare it for processing. Sometimes you have to tease apart the yarns a little bit.

sense.name: TEASE APART: Disambiguate or disentangle information for the purpose of identification.
sense.examples: Sometimes it's difficult to tease apart issues in political rhetoric. This book could help tease apart what it takes to be a good dad. We sought to tease apart what impact the experiment might have.

sense.name: Ruffle (one's hair) by combing the ends towards the scalp, for a full effect.
sense.examples: The stylist teased her hair for a half hour. John teased his hair to make it really big.

sense.name: Extract information from someone or something.
sense.examples: Mary teased the truth from the mass of John's lies and half-truths. He was able to tease out some truth from the opaque manuscript. She teased the information out of him.
